title: Tutorial: Parallelizing Work with DSPy.rb
description:
Write a tutorial demonstrating how to parallelize LLM work in DSPy.rb.

**Primary Use Case**: Naming a conversation while answering the user's request simultaneously.

When a user sends their first message, the system needs to:
1. Generate a response to the user's question
2. Generate a title/name for the conversation

These two tasks are independent and can run in parallel, reducing latency.

**Tutorial Should Cover**:
- Using Async gem with DSPy.rb modules
- Running multiple predictions concurrently
- Error handling for parallel operations
- When parallelization makes sense vs sequential execution
- Performance considerations and tradeoffs

**Example Code Structure**:
```ruby
Async do |task|
  response_task = task.async { responder.predict(message: user_message) }
  title_task = task.async { titler.predict(messages: [user_message]) }
  
  response = response_task.wait
  title = title_task.wait
end
```

title: Unsafe deserialization in program storage

title: Command injection in GitHub CLI toolset
description: shell_escape() only escapes double quotes, allowing injection via backticks or $() (lib/dspy/tools/github_cli_toolset.rb:268-278). Fix: use Shellwords.shellescape or Open3.capture3 with array args.

title: Command injection in text processing toolset
description: grep/ripgrep methods use shell backticks with user patterns without escaping (lib/dspy/tools/text_processing_toolset.rb:43-44, 82-86). Pattern can break out of single quotes. Fix: use Ruby regex or Shellwords.shellescape.

title: CodeAct eval() arbitrary code execution vulnerability
description: CRITICAL: CodeAct uses Ruby eval() to execute LLM-generated code without sandboxing (lib/dspy/code_act.rb:400-428). An attacker could craft prompts causing malicious code execution. Solutions: container isolation, safe_ruby gem, or static analysis allowlist.
